com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.swing

Class PSwingUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.swing.PSwingUtils

  • public final class PSwingUtils
extends Object
    Collection of static methods that builds upon SwingUtilities.

    Note about argument types: Where possible the least derived class is used for method arguments. For widgets, this is frequently one of:

    • Component: from Abstract Window Toolkit (base class of most AWT/Swing widgets)
    • Container: also from Abstract Window Toolkit (derived from Component)
    • JComponent: from Swing toolkiet (derived from Container)
    Author:
    Kevin Connor ARPE (kevinarpe@gmail.com)

    • Method Detail

      • isComponentShowing

        public static boolean isComponentShowing(Component comp)
        Tests if a Component is showing, which is defined by three sub-tests:
        1. showing via Component.isShowing()
        2. has a parent window via SwingUtilities.getWindowAncestor(Component)
        3. the parent window is showing via Component.isShowing()
        Parameters:
        comp - reference to an AWT/Swing widget
        Returns:
        true if widget is showing
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if comp is null

      • buttonDoClickAfterNextShow

        public static void buttonDoClickAsync(AbstractButton button)

      • runAfterNextShow

        public static void runAfterNextShow(Component comp,
                    Runnable run)
        Runs a callback only after the next show event. One or two listeners are installed (and later uninstalled) to correctly capture the show event. (This is trickier than many realize!) The intent of this method is to provide a safe way to modify a Component after its next show. Example: The original JSplitPane did not allow proportional divider location to be correctly set until the widget was shown. What a pain! (Grrr.)

        Some caveats:

        • The callback is always run from the Event Dispatch Thread.
        • To better understand the term "showing", see isComponentShowing(Component).
        • The term "next" is applied strictly: If the component is showing when this method is called, the code will not run until the widget is hidden, then shown again. The method runIfShowingOrAfterNextShow(Component, Runnable) exists to handle this issue.
        Parameters:
        comp - reference to an AWT/Swing widget
        run - callback to run
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if comp or run is null
        See Also:
        isComponentShowing(Component), runIfShowingOrAfterNextShow(Component, Runnable)

      • runIfShowingOrAfterNextShow

        public static boolean runIfShowingOrAfterNextShow(Component comp,
                                  Runnable run)
        Given a callback:
        • if widget is showing, run via SwingUtilities.invokeLater(Runnable)
        • else, run via runAfterNextShow(Component, Runnable)

        Some caveats:

        • The callback is always run from the Event Dispatch Thread.
        • To better understand the term "showing", see isComponentShowing(Component).
        Parameters:
        comp - reference to an AWT/Swing widget
        run - callback to run
        Returns:
        true is widget is showing
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if comp or run is null
        See Also:
        isComponentShowing(Component), runAfterNextShow(Component, Runnable)
